The population is composed Of Creole.

she could not enter in consequence of the
land breeze. Apparently she was waiting
till morning for that purpose; but during the

landed 450 slaves a little to the windward
and having in this way quieted the suspicious
ot the British commandant on that station
she next day entered as sin ballast" So
provoked was the officer, that on boarding
her, he even ordered her sails upfurled 70
see ifhc could not find one slave at least. that
he might condemn the vessel He missed

The slave trade is carried on, however.


from the coast OF Africa 10 the Brazls and


Cuba, more even at the present time than
most persons IN our own country believe


There are $50 vessels called traders, en-


ployed IN this business. and what is sufficient


to make a man blush for the United States.


many OF her citizens are engaged in it. The


crews, commanders, and sometimes owners


Of these vessels, are from our northern ci-
ties, and, while they sustain fair characters.


are secretly plunderng Africa to crafty


their avarice. The temptation, to be sure is


great. A slave can be bought in Africa at


about $40, and when he touches the shores
OF Cuba is worth from 400 to $500. Great


caution is of course necessary in this pro-
, ceedins; and hence all flags are hoisted and
all articles resurtcd to which the occasion
may requirc The writer of this is not
speaking without information; nor are these

: idencc.


A small Spanish schooner arrived at Ma

She landed them before coming to port but

In 1899, Mir. M'kean was elected govern
or of PENNSYLVANIA. His election was the
result of a warm conflict between the two
great parties which were then assuming
those distinct political ranks, into which,
for many years, the people OF our country
continue to be divided. 1t is unnecessary to
specify the political changes and occurrences
prcparatory to, and causing his election IN
preference to his distinguished and able COM
petitor--the honourable James Ross. His
success, through what was termed the ms
mentum Of PENNSYLVANIA politics" paved
the way for the accession of Mr. Jefferson to
the presidency; and during the whole peri
od of that gcntleman's administration, the
weight of Mr.. MKcan's opinions and CON
duct was directed to the upholding OF the
principles which marked the policy OF the
general government.


Towards the close of the year 1905, he
was strongly solicited to become candidate
for the Office of Vice President OF the Unit
cd States. MIR. M'Kean declined this hon
or, both on public and private considerations
/ Towards the close Of the eighteenth cen
tury. the French revolution excited much
interest in America Mr.. M kean naturally
and conscientiously imbbed strong prepos-
sessions in favor Of French liberty, i'll CON
junction with the members OF the party To
which he was attached. Many years after
his retirement from public life, an interest
inc correspondence on this subject took place
between him and the honorable John Adams,
who had. from, the outset, viewed the revo-


luton in France with aprophetic eye. Va
the second of June, 1872, Mr.. Adams thus
opened the subject. "Nearly thirty-cight
wears ago, our friendship commenced. II
has never been interrupted to my kno~l-
edge but bv ono event. Among all the gen
tlemen with whom have acted and lived III
the world, | know not any two VINO nave
mere uniformly agreed in sentimeht upon
political principles, forms Of goI trnmeut


and national policy, than yon and have
done, except upon one great SUBJECT; Amos


important and lnomen'ous one to he sure; =


that subject was, the Frencb Revolution =


This, at the first appearance oFit, you though
a minister Of grace;' fully believed to b'
goblin damned


In person, Mr. NJ 'hcan was tail, erect
and well proportiohed. His conntcnanc'


displayed, in Il remarkable manner, thu


6rmness and Intelligence for which he Wa


distinguished. Ills manners we're impressive


and diSnihed.


At length. loaded with hpnours. this ven


cradle patriot arrived al the WtiriY a0ca RE-


rum, and departed to "the generation q ~


fathers" on the twenty fourth q 1u'e
| 1917, aged eighty three Years, two months
i and sixteen days His remains were interre,
in the burial ground Of the first Prcsh}
! tcrian church, IN Market street, Phi.atiel
5 phia.


Thomas NJ 'kean outivcd all the enmitie
which an active and conspicuous part III pub


lie affairs had, III the nature Of things, ere
ated; and posterity will centinns TO chcris
his memory, as one among the mo4t useful
able, and >iltuous fathers OF M sh;y rtpu5
lic

One thousand casks of Beef, and two hun
lred casks Of Pork, have arrived in London
from Boston, in the United States. They
were Inspected on Friday, and were found
to be Of hrtme qra}4y Though these pro-

Pointer sr.---Samson Paul, an Indian, living
on a small island in Lake George, while QUE
spearing FISH. discovered large Panther
swimming towards him. Leaving the fish,
to combatwith his new enemy, he commenc-
ei an attack. by first peltins the pan
ther with stones. Nothing daunted at this.
however, the panther boldly advanced upon
the Indian, and the lndan as boldly recelv-
ed him upon the point of his spear, and with
the first thrust he put an eye out, and the
next struck him III the throat, and held him
under water till he was drowned. The
Panther measured seven feet three inches
from the tip Of his nose to the end of his tail

On the twenty eighth of July, liz, he
received from the supreme executive cohh-
Gil. the commission of chief justice OF Penn-
sylyania, and performed the duties OF that
high station with distinguished zeal and II
delity for twenty-five years At the time OF
his appointment, he was speaker OF the
house of assembly, president OF Delaware
and member of Congress.


On the tenth of July, 1871. he was, on the
resignation of the honorable Samuel Hunt
ineton, President of Congress. On the TWEEN
ty-third of October, 1881, the following let
ter was laid before that body by the secre-
tary:


.sS1H, ! must beg you to remind Congress,
that when they did me the honor OF ei'ctlng
me president, and before l assumed the
chair, informed them, that, as chief JUS
tce of Pennsylvania, / should be under the
necessity of attending the supreme court OF
that state, in the latter end of September or
at farthest, in October. The court will be
held to day. l must, therefore, request,
chat they will be pleased to proceed TO the
chce of another president"


Congress accepted the resignation OF MIR.
MKean, but postponed the election Of
president until the next day, when, on no
tion of DR.. Witherspoon, was unanimously
resolved, that Mr.. M'kean be requested to
resume the chair, and act as president, I'M
til the first Monday in November, the rcso-
luton of the previous day, accepting his re
sgnation Notwithstanding. 10 this meas
ure he acceded. On the fifth of November,
the honorable John Hanson was elected pres
ident on the seventh, it was "ReSoived, that
the thank of congress be given to the hohor-
able Thomas M'Kean, late president Of
congress, in testimony Of their appreciation
of his conduct in the chair, and in the exc
cution of public business


Independent Of his principles and conduct,
Mr.. NJ MKean, as chief justice OF Pennsylva-
MIA, performed the duties of his office with
impartiality and infexibilty. During the
progress of the revolution, Philadelphia be-
ing the seat of general government, and an
object of peculiar watchfulness on the part
of the enemy. the just performance Of MIR.





the learning of the lawyer, but the unyield-
ng spirit of the patriot. Proclaiming from
he bench, the law of Justice and his coun-
try with distinguished learning, ability and
integrity, neither fear, nor power, could
bend him from the stern line of duty. ke-
gardless Of the powers Of the crown Of Great
Britain, he did not hesitate to hazard hi,
own life, by causing to be punished, even un
70 DEATH those who were proved TO be trai.
tors to their country


But no popular excitement against individ-
uals accused Of offences, could, in the slight
est degree, divert him from the firm and in
flexible discharge of his public duty. His de.
cision in favor ofSamuel Chapman, Data,
Tehorts, vol j. $50 e,inced the souudness o
his judgment, and the disdain he felt for tht
popular Glamour, excited by the occasion.


His firmncss in the execution of the laws
is eXemplihed by another striking example
In 1878, he issued warrant against Colonc
Robert l.. Hooper Col. Hooper waited ol
General Greene, then quarter-master-g
eral, to inquire whether the circumstance
of the army would admit Of his absence
Gen. Greene, in letter to Mr.. M'Kean
dated Camp, Valley Forge, third June 1873
observed, among other things relative to th
subject, that, a the army was Just on tn
wing, he could not, without great necessity
"conSent" to Col. Hooper's being absent
This direct interference of the military will
The civil authority, reused the official spiri
of the Chief Justice, and occasoned the fol
towing severe, but just answer:


81 do not think, sir. that the absence, sick
ness, CT even death of Mr.. Hooper, could b
attended with such consequence that u
ether tersoD could be found who could CIV
the necessary aid upon this occasion: bu
what attracts my attention the most, is you
observation that yon cannot, without grea
necessity, consent 10 lis beng abScnt. AS t
That, ] shall not ask l2fsr consent, nor tina
Of any other person, IN or out of the army
whether my precept shall be obeyed or na
in Pennsylvania.


i he warrant for the arrest Of Mr.. Hope
being special, no other Magistrate can tax
cognizance theseof but myself The mod
you propose, of giving bail, cannot be adopt
ed, for many reasons.


should be very sorry to find that the e.;
ecution of criminal law should impede til
operations of the army, in any instance; br
much more so, to find the latter impede tn
former"


Mr.. NJ Kean industriously devoted himse
tothe discharge ofthe duties Of chief ustc
until the year 1893, when he was electe
governor of the commonwealth of Pennsy
yania. In all the qualifications of Ii
Judge, it may, without hesitation, be saic
that be had but few equals in this,

tens;cc cotton factories in blackburn. nc
for some time retired from business IN Ian
cashire. and principally resided IN Cheshlre,
where he has purchased large estates anu

wear. lie has an only daughter, now turned
of 16 wears of age, and who IS the presuup-
five heiress of his wealth. lhIs young i1uy
was wear ago, resident tor her cuuca

notice Of Miss DAVIS, (since married TO
Mr.. Wakefield, the father OF the defendants
at the late trial who resided 10 Maccies-
Geld not lar from Mr. Turner's residence
Miss Davis appears to have speculated TO
ret Miss Turner by cohh DE- man lot one
Of the YOUNGER Wake efields-both the WAKE
fields and Miss Davis were entire strangers
to Miss Turner, aul abduction was the only
way to effect their purpose. Stratagcm was
uscd--the young lady was purlolneu ifoni
her schnol by Edward Gibson Wakefield,
and induced to submit to one OF the disgrace
full Gretna-green marriages, under the no.
tiou. artfully impressed upon her by Wake
field. that her Father had been suddenly lu-
ned by the failure of the country Banks,
but that his (Wakcield's) uncle, rich
banker, was to establish him upon tins mar

1i,a. Regina Maria Roche.--In the days
Of her celebrity, Mrs. Roche enjoyed ease,
comfort, and popularity: her friends were
numerous, and their Kindness was at her
command. She then declined to avail her
self of an unlimited offer of services from
Sir William tdamsqn, Governor Of Jamaica,
to whom the "Childrcn of the Abbey" had
been dedicated, because, as she emphatlcai-
" says, "she had then little reason to ap-
prehend what She has suffered" Trying,
indeed has been her reverse OF fate; bereft
of health. reduced in fortune and friends her
lot presents true example Of the instability
of human happiness.

Stage diSaster.-The Albany Daily AdVer-
tlser states that on Saturday evening week
as one of the northern stages was on the wa!
to Albany with nine passengers, IN crossing
the bridge over Moscskili. in the town OF
Fort Edward, Washington coanty' INC
bridge gave way. when the stage, passsh-
gers and horses we're preciptated into inc
stream, and a man, womaa, and ooy
were drowned. together with two ot the
horses. The names of the persons drowned
are not known; they were Irish emigransS,
lately landed at Quebec. rhc bridge ha!
been recently built. but the stream beng
much swollen by the late rains, i is suppo'-
ed that the water had washed round and uh'
lernined one of the abutments which caoS'
Ell the disaster.

eli statement purporting to be oHici.,
which the same number is given as f,, ~ y
as 1917. But this probably included c"as
abaccoa, distant one league from the c;...
and containing about 20 900 inhabitants
the place has. however, increased r.r;J's
since that period. the above will, thint hyS
found not far from the truth. W


The population is composed Of Creole.
Spaniards. slaves and free negroes. Mo-
of the latter were imported from Africa ~
fore the Spanish and English governmsnt
entered into their present treaty on this sub.
ject, and some since. For the execution -
this treaty, there is established at Havana -
ommission, called "Commison mista ),
and judge from each of these goyernmer..
has been appointed. Henry T. Klbee Fso
is there at the present time, on the part &c
the English. In addition to these. th,rn
are usually one or more men ot.war station.
ed at Havana, which have the privilege os
examining any vessels under any far II
cases OF suspicion. In January last, a French
vessel appeared off the Moro. and made III,
signal for a man-of-war. AS it was eyenne
she could not enter in consequence of the
land breeze. Apparently she was waiting
till morning for that purpose; but during the
night She took advantage of the current
landed 450 slaves a little to the windward
and having in this way quieted the suspicious
ot the British commandant on that station
she next day entered as sin ballast" So
provoked was the officer, that on boarding
her, he even ordered her sails upfurled 70
see ifhc could not find one slave at least. that
he might condemn the vessel He missed
his prize, however, and had to confess him


self out generated.


The slave trade is carried on, however.


from the coast OF Africa 10 the Brazls and


Cuba, more even at the present time than
most persons IN our own country believe


There are $50 vessels called traders, en-


ployed IN this business. and what is sufficient


to make a man blush for the United States.


many OF her citizens are engaged in it. The


crews, commanders, and sometimes owners


Of these vessels, are from our northern ci-
ties, and, while they sustain fair characters.


are secretly plunderng Africa to crafty


their avarice. The temptation, to be sure is


great. A slave can be bought in Africa at


about $40, and when he touches the shores
OF Cuba is worth from 400 to $500. Great


caution is of course necessary in this pro-
, ceedins; and hence all flags are hoisted and
all articles resurtcd to which the occasion
may requirc The writer of this is not
speaking without information; nor are these
assertions founded on any thing less than ev-
: idencc.


A small Spanish schooner arrived at Ma


tanzas. in February, with $50 slaves, atho'
; she could not be above 80 tons burthen--
She landed them before coming to port but


on the second or third day the slaves were
' introduced into the city-emaciated-al
: most naked, with an air Of dcspondency and
grief which their situation was well cacu-
lated to inspire.

was perfect; but never saw equalied, ms
dignity of manner, in delivering charge to
jury, or on a law argument, to the par
But what is still more, his comprehension OF
mind in taking notes, SO as to enhance the
subject, and yet omit nothing material, mas
appeared to me inimitable."


In 1899, Mir. M'kean was elected govern
or of PENNSYLVANIA. His election was the
result of a warm conflict between the two
great parties which were then assuming
those distinct political ranks, into which,
for many years, the people OF our country
continue to be divided. 1t is unnecessary to
specify the political changes and occurrences
prcparatory to, and causing his election IN
preference to his distinguished and able COM
petitor--the honourable James Ross. His
success, through what was termed the ms
mentum Of PENNSYLVANIA politics" paved
the way for the accession of Mr. Jefferson to
the presidency; and during the whole peri
od of that gcntleman's administration, the
weight of Mr.. MKcan's opinions and CON
duct was directed to the upholding OF the
principles which marked the policy OF the
general government.


Towards the close of the year 1905, he
was strongly solicited to become candidate
for the Office of Vice President OF the Unit
cd States. MIR. M'Kean declined this hon
or, both on public and private considerations
/ Towards the close Of the eighteenth cen
tury. the French revolution excited much
interest in America Mr.. M kean naturally
and conscientiously imbbed strong prepos-
sessions in favor Of French liberty, i'll CON
junction with the members OF the party To
which he was attached. Many years after
his retirement from public life, an interest
inc correspondence on this subject took place
between him and the honorable John Adams,
who had. from, the outset, viewed the revo-


luton in France with aprophetic eye. Va
the second of June, 1872, Mr.. Adams thus
opened the subject. "Nearly thirty-cight
wears ago, our friendship commenced. II
has never been interrupted to my kno~l-
edge but bv ono event. Among all the gen
tlemen with whom have acted and lived III
the world, | know not any two VINO nave
mere uniformly agreed in sentimeht upon
political principles, forms Of goI trnmeut


and national policy, than yon and have
done, except upon one great SUBJECT; Amos


important and lnomen'ous one to he sure; =


that subject was, the Frencb Revolution =


This, at the first appearance oFit, you though
a minister Of grace;' fully believed to b'
goblin damned


In person, Mr. NJ 'hcan was tail, erect
and well proportiohed. His conntcnanc'


displayed, in Il remarkable manner, thu


6rmness and Intelligence for which he Wa


distinguished. Ills manners we're impressive


and diSnihed.


At length. loaded with hpnours. this ven


cradle patriot arrived al the WtiriY a0ca RE-


rum, and departed to "the generation q ~


fathers" on the twenty fourth q 1u'e
| 1917, aged eighty three Years, two months
i and sixteen days His remains were interre,
in the burial ground Of the first Prcsh}
! tcrian church, IN Market street, Phi.atiel
5 phia.


Thomas NJ 'kean outivcd all the enmitie
which an active and conspicuous part III pub


lie affairs had, III the nature Of things, ere
ated; and posterity will centinns TO chcris
his memory, as one among the mo4t useful
able, and >iltuous fathers OF M sh;y rtpu5
lic


5 u -. -.

full articles.headline: Lend2n, April 4.
full articles.article:
One thousand casks of Beef, and two hun
lred casks Of Pork, have arrived in London
from Boston, in the United States. They
were Inspected on Friday, and were found
to be Of hrtme qra}4y Though these pro-
visions cannot be landed but for export to
our foreign dependencies or possr ssious, the
circumstances show the great advance made
by foreign nations. 1t is likely, wc should
think, that this meat, as beng equal in quail
ity to British or IRISH, viii be purchased by
the Conmlssriht for Our army in Portugal.
This is a blow TO the landed interest, which
no system CT Corn Laws Will be enabled to
cure.

full articles.article:
Cuba was discovered in llS0, by Column
bus, who appointed Diego Valasqnes Gov
ernor To him there were Is successors
acting in the same capacity; until the year
1904, at which time tiaspar Ruis de Pereda
was appointed at Havana, w.ta the title of
Captain General OF the Island Down to
this day, there have been in all II chiefs, in
Guiding General Wives, the present Govern
or. The island was occupied ia one place
on the south Side, as early as 1906; but Ha-
vsna was not settled till 1871. Its locality
rendered it favorable situation for vessels
from the variou. p.It; OF the Gulf IT Mexi-
CO, to stop at; and that at first caused its
growth. This place has also been the de-
pot Ct great wealth, and particularly. since
the revolution in South America These
events have driv IN the old Span,ar,ts from
the new republics; and many Of then who
have brosSht wealth with them, have set
tied in Havana, in preference to returning 10
Spain.


! The population of the Havana NAV be es.
| timated, at the present time, at about 40.
Oo0; not more than half Of which is probably
within the walls. This number is given. al
ter having examined the subject as far as
4 possible, in place where taking public
census is viewed with so much jealousy. tho,
even one Oh the commissioners appojnted r.
TINS duty, ridiculed the report which he and


others had made. The usual estimate n


the residents is higher; and this NAV be


looked upon as the medium Of different onin,


ions, Mr. pnincetr IN SIC ,,,-..,. eF'

Pointer sr.---Samson Paul, an Indian, living
on a small island in Lake George, while QUE
spearing FISH. discovered large Panther
swimming towards him. Leaving the fish,
to combatwith his new enemy, he commenc-
ei an attack. by first peltins the pan
ther with stones. Nothing daunted at this.
however, the panther boldly advanced upon
the Indian, and the lndan as boldly recelv-
ed him upon the point of his spear, and with
the first thrust he put an eye out, and the
next struck him III the throat, and held him
under water till he was drowned. The
Panther measured seven feet three inches
from the tip Of his nose to the end of his tail

Twas compelled to remove my family hve

On the twenty eighth of July, liz, he
received from the supreme executive cohh-
Gil. the commission of chief justice OF Penn-
sylyania, and performed the duties OF that
high station with distinguished zeal and II
delity for twenty-five years At the time OF
his appointment, he was speaker OF the
house of assembly, president OF Delaware
and member of Congress.


On the tenth of July, 1871. he was, on the
resignation of the honorable Samuel Hunt
ineton, President of Congress. On the TWEEN
ty-third of October, 1881, the following let
ter was laid before that body by the secre-
tary:


.sS1H, ! must beg you to remind Congress,
that when they did me the honor OF ei'ctlng
me president, and before l assumed the
chair, informed them, that, as chief JUS
tce of Pennsylvania, / should be under the
necessity of attending the supreme court OF
that state, in the latter end of September or
at farthest, in October. The court will be
held to day. l must, therefore, request,
chat they will be pleased to proceed TO the
chce of another president"


Congress accepted the resignation OF MIR.
MKean, but postponed the election Of
president until the next day, when, on no
tion of DR.. Witherspoon, was unanimously
resolved, that Mr.. M'kean be requested to
resume the chair, and act as president, I'M
til the first Monday in November, the rcso-
luton of the previous day, accepting his re
sgnation Notwithstanding. 10 this meas
ure he acceded. On the fifth of November,

1i,a. Regina Maria Roche.--In the days
Of her celebrity, Mrs. Roche enjoyed ease,
comfort, and popularity: her friends were
numerous, and their Kindness was at her
command. She then declined to avail her
self of an unlimited offer of services from
Sir William tdamsqn, Governor Of Jamaica,
to whom the "Childrcn of the Abbey" had
been dedicated, because, as she emphatlcai-
" says, "she had then little reason to ap-
prehend what She has suffered" Trying,
indeed has been her reverse OF fate; bereft
of health. reduced in fortune and friends her
lot presents true example Of the instability
of human happiness.
